habitat_description: The Cascade Caverns salamander is described from the Cascade Caverns in Kendall County, Texas (Smith and Potter 1946). This single population consists of individuals displaying a wide spectrum of morphological features, from cave-associated morphologies, to surface-like morphologies (Green et al. 2013). Although, it has been theorized that the shift in morphologies may be due to hybridization with surface-dwelling salamanders, Chippindale et al. (2000) found no evidence of hybrids. This species is only known from caves that contain water and surrounding outflows; individuals are found under submerged rocks, mud substrate, while individuals associated with springs are found under rocks, leaves, and substrate.
